topic.title: bug with connections limit
topic.body:
I got lots of this in logs:
DEBUG    FileServer Conn#45335 (IP) [?] > Closing connection: (IP) Connect error: IOError: cannot watch more than 1024 sockets in ConnectionServer.py line 142 > Connection.py line 107 > socket.py line 242 > core.pyx line 468 > core.pyx line 813, waiting_requests: 0, sites: 0, buff: 0...
Tray menu shows near the same value.
The actual problem is zn drops localhost connections too, so i can't access zites in the browser.
I think there must be exception for that, first of all, plus some logic limiting connections, probably related to a peer count on each site hosted.
// Yes, i have many zites connected.

1_1APx2pf1wNGFz4mWCN2sFzrtTGzrLKZUQ2.body:
was 3094, now updated to 3125. will look for changes

.. okay. now tray says connections ~2000 and site is not responding again.

version 0.6.1 rev 3223 - problem still here.
 zn taking more and more connections upon start, and after some hours it bumps to some limit over 1000.
So i think here we need improvements in 2 areas:
- For those who like to host many sitez, there should be option to raise or unlock top limit, and/or add new limits for lowering connections to any particular site. I can see in stats some sites hold 10...20 connections opened.
If the site has many other peers besides me, i'd prefer to serve it as less as possible.
- Since it is obvious, sites tend to pile up in users cache, some cleanup function should be added, with logic simple as this: if the site was not requested (remotely or by me) for some time (configurable of course, like a month or year) - delete it, IF there is enough other peers serving it. or any. or do not count this. This function may be triggered once a day and display standart message, saying "there are some megabytes you may save, press here" or the like

Bitmessage is currently flooded with spam and there is no easy countermeasure for that. It results in heavy traffic and cpu usage. Public chats are unusable as of now.
Retroshare distant chat is fast and reliable, if you are well connected. Anonymity beyond your trusted peers is granted by message relaying logic, and no tor or i2p layer required.

ipfs was designed as future replacement of torrent, that is already obsolete but is currently used in zeronet.
when it is mature enough, it may be reasonable to move zn on it's rails
